content: \forall x, x : Empty is false. What is the type T that satisfies: \forall x, x : T?

There is no such type. In Lean, every term has only one type (up to definitional equality). The key question is: What is the type of x in your \forall x, ...? In lean every forall quantifier needs to have a type bound on it. If it's \forall x : T, then of course x : T in that context, but for terms of other types, they will not have type T. Lean does not really have subtyping at the logical level (although it fakes it to some extent using coercions at the elaborator level).
